column1: Between 11 March 2022 and 9 September 2022, will Russia publicly announce that it has moved nuclear weapons into either Belarus or Ukraine?
column6: ['Technology', 'Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']

While it is true that back in June Putin declared that Russia would move nuclear weapons into Belarus (source: https://www.usip.org/publications/2022/06/possible-russian-nuclear-deployments-belarus-could-shift-europes-nuclear), the probability that this will come to fruition by the closing date of this question in 6 hours is vanishingly close to zero. However, the fact that this question still retains a consensus view of only 97% "no" indicates to me that there may be some evidence I am not considering. Perhaps, the seemingly arbitrary closing date of this question (September 10) has some relevance in Russia or in the Russian army and that is swaying agreement by 3%. Or, perhaps, the 3% is indicative of earlier disagreement when this question first opened. Maybe then, people believed that the chances of Russia moving nukes was x = 50% or even x > 50%, and those early predictions have tilted the average today. Of course, I cannot assign a value of 0% to this question, because the probability of a Russia nuclear transit by early tomorrow morning eventuality is not equal to 0, but I have near full confidence that this will not occur within the next 6 hours, and therefore, assign a value of 1%.
Why would Russia do this? They can nuke almost anywhere in the world from Russia.
Updating for passage of time. Thankful to say no chance.
Less than 24 hours to go.
No sign to happen as the deadline for this question approaches

Russia will fear the public and military retaliation of NATO members. With NATO countries Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia along the Russian border, Russia may fear that nuclear weapons will be placed very close to their borders if they bring nuclear weapons into Ukraine. I am also making this prediction in the final 3 days of this 6 month period, so the chances of it occurring now are far less likely. The conflict in Ukraine has generally simmered down at this point, with the city of Kiev more or less going back to work and school normally.
No, there have been no signs of this with 2 days left.
its almost that date and they haven't, it is super unlikely that they do, I think it 100% won't happen
It seems Moscow now prefers to use energy as a leverage against the West instead of its Nuclear weapons.
Not likely in the next few days
Putin is certainly angry with the result of his scheming, but he‚Äôs focused on driving the energy crisis toward European recession. Nuclear posturing would serve to obscure his larger focus.
I doubt that Russia actually has mobile nuclear weapons at this point. From the various reports all their equipment is badly maintained archaic garbage.

I still have an issue with "publicly" announce. I find that it's strategically better to keep it secret. Plus, during the Cuban Missile Crisis, recon had to prove this type of stuff existed in Cuba. I"m not sure if they publicly admitted to it later on though. I can see why Russia WOULD want it to be publicly known but then again there are reasons to tame down this speculation for publicly announcing it. In other words, really unlikely in the next 9 days.
Call me crazy but ICBMs *checks notes* still exist...The only 0.01% chance this resolves "yes" is as a tactical threat/posture perspective this is announced.
Correcting my forecast yesterday. I meant to forecast 0% that Russia will announce.
Doing so would not help with the long game (attrition). Focus now is on conscription.
Apparently there's been some sort of paperwork snafu trying to get some of the needed data from the Mar-a-Lago storage facility.
Focus completely shifted
With the time left, much closer to 0% than 1% now.
Not his way, he might use them but he would blame someone else
Russia has no military need to use nuclear weapons in Ukraine, Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu said Tuesday.
There is strategic benefit from this action, it is not an effective threat.

There's 31 days between now and then. Assuming something major would have to change in either the course of the war or the relationship with the West. The major developments happening now are Ukraine's offensive and the damage to the nuclear facility in Ukraine. It seems like Russia would only have reason to threaten nuclear weapons if Ukraine's offensive was spectacularly successful, like to the point of reaching/exceeding pre-invasion borders. I don't think Ukraine can totally restore borders yet and there's no reason for them to extend into Russia.
Holding my 0%.

Updating for passage of time. Russia appears to be using every weapon in it's arsenal except nukes, from the tried and true (suppress dissent) to the Far Out - literally. This week, Russia announced, amended, then all but retracted its plan to vacate the International Space Station, in favor of a DIY version.
"World stands on ‚Äòabyss of nuclear war‚Äô over Ukraine conflict, says Lukashenko"
No announcement will be made Putin will ignore the President of Belarus as he is looked on as weak in the eyes of Russia , they are possibly there already in the form of Mobil launchers.

Russia seems set to contain the conflict to Ukraine and has not expressed intentions to move nuclear arsenal as response to SV & FI joining NATO. Russia's best strategic bet for winning Ukraine is to put economic pressure on Europe (gas shortage, oil prices) to split support for Ukraine which would increase pressure on Ukraine from some allies to sue for peace by giving up territory. Nuclear escalation would solidify view of Russia as serious threat and undermine this strategy.
Math is difficult. 95% chance of not announcing this means this questions answer is 5% :)
Placing missiles in Belarus still seems to be a cheap mean to create confusion in the NATO states.
Might bluff by moving. Again, unless Putin is truly sick or needs a miracle to stay in power unlikely given the current path of war.

I don't think this will happen. It would escalade tensions between the West and Russia. Which would mean, more Western weapons for Ukraine, more NATO troops in (Eastern) Europe. And on the other side Belarus is trying to stay out of the confict as well and deploying onto Ukrainian territory, well in that case... what would happen if the Ukrainians would pull it off to actually capture (some of) that nukes. I don't think that the Russians want to risk something like that. Maayyybe Crimea miiiight be an option for Russia to deploy nuclear weapons. But still highly unlikely. Generously 3%.
Belarus wants to stay clere from the war. Bringing nuclear weapons into Ukrain could provoce WW3.
The important bit from recent news (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61938111) is that Russia is supposedly going to send missile systems to Belarus within months.

#BREAKING Moscow to send Belarus missiles able to carry nuclear warheads within months: Putin

I'm skeptical because it requires a public statement. However, I wouldn't be surprised if conditions develop into a situation where the drama of nuclear weapons pushes Russian leaders to make such a statement. But I won't go up too much until I see chemical weapons. THEN I'd be convinced Russia "isn't playing games."
it seems Belarus is trying to distance itself from the conflict, and staging of nuclear weapons will be a major escalation for both Russia and Minsk.

Iskander nuclear capable missiles were moved into the Brest Belarus area. I dont believe that Putin would use or announce movement of nukes as it would probably trigger NATO involvement in war
It seems unlikely now, considering the effort Lukashenko invested in keeping Belarus away from the conflict.

"Russia to set up military base in Kherson - reportsThe Russian-appointed administration in Kherson, southern Ukraine, will ask Moscow to set up a military base on its territory, Russia's RIA news agency reports, citing a government official.Kirill Stremousov, the deputy head of what Russia calls the "civil-military regional administration" of Kherson, told RIA: "There should be a Russian military base in the Kherson region."We will ask for this and this is what the whole population wants. "This is essential and will be a guarantor of security for the region and its inhabitants."For context: The city of Kherson, which straddles both the Dnieper River and the Black Sea in southern Ukraine, was one of the first regions to fall under Russian control. Analysts say the area is strategically valuable as controlling it would allow Russia to block Ukraine's access to the sea and link territories in Donetsk and Luhansk with Crimea."

Outcome seems highly unlikely; both in general context with historical MAD-doctrines usage of nukes as baseline, and the tactical movements, statements and events to follow since the 27th of February leading up to the invasion.

I think that the Russian generals would prevent this from happening, at the moment hostilities are confined to Ukraine, and between Russia and Ukraine armed forces. Deploying nuclear weapons would be an open invitation for the nuclear armed countries of NATO to become involved and puts Russian territory in peril.
While it's difficult to separate the fact from fiction coming out of anyone at the moment, I am a nuclear optimist on this conflict.
Initial forecast
I think probability of this outcome is increasing every day as Russia feels cornered in the international arena and invasion becomes a war of attrition.

A lot can but it would be an easy way to zone off UAF from a combat zone if Russian AF were to store nuclear weapons in the occupied territories. Probably can increase over time if Russia feels cornered, NATO admission for Sweden & Finland.
That would be a move that increases pressure on EU. So I think this looks more attractive from the Russian side the longer the war continues.

Moving nuclear weapons into another country implies the ability to maintain possession of them. (Belarus signaled that Russia could if Russia wanted to +1.) Moving them and announcing that you are doing so suggests that you are warning NATO not to intervene. There are no signs that NATO intends to intervene. (Allowing that recent deployments of NATO troops to countries bordering Ukraine could be interpreted as preparation for intervention +1).

Dmitry Peskov has said that if Finland and Sweden joined Nato then Russia would have to ‚Äúrebalance the situation‚Äù with its own measures. So either he‚Äôs opening a new Nando‚Äôs franchise on the border or it‚Äôs Iskander‚Äôs to Belarus.

Just a question for clarification. Would is deployment to Crimea actually count moving them into Ukraine? That would I be my option, if I'd thinking to move nuclear weapons westwards. Cause, they would be as close to "mainland" Ukraine as they would be in Donbass or Belarus. And use it probably as a deterent in case the Ukrainians are actually thinking about taking Crimea back. So nukes in Crimea would work as deterent as well as strengthen the Russian position in negotiations.
This event is highly unlikely given the outcomes of including nuclear instruments into the conflict. Again, the cost calculus would exclude such irrational risk levels.

As NATO reinforces allies that border Russia it seems like a likely step that Russia might respond by putting nukes in Belarus especially as it shows no signs of deescalating the war in Ukraine and more sanctions against Russia are likely.
small chance high consequence of such a move. In that time frame, more likely Belarus (not as directly in the hot line of fire)
Putin may well do it, but he won't announce it.

This is contingent on how desperate they are in taking the Donbas by force. Nuclear saber-rattling is a tool to help tip the bargaining leverage in the negotiators favor in Russia. Putin has already demonstrated his proclivity to mentioning nuclear weapons - the next step in the bargaining tet-a-tet would be to move actual weapons around as a scare tactic.
Could be a response to NATO moving nuclear weapons to Poland, but that is unlikely. Belarus itself doesn't look very keen to part of the conflict at the moment.

The operators working to defend Ukraine alongside citizens are truly stifling the Russian advance, and with a loss of top commanders, it appears Putin will be forced to potentially concede his invasion altogether or risk losing what gains he has made; It could be trickery, as the agreed pull-back in forces around Kyiv made just be misdirection to allow the fortification of Mariupol so as to not be forced to relinquish what is one of the most vital assets of the Crimean region before advancing again, but the losses they are suffering must surely be affecting them in many ways.
Only if Putin is not "removed" from office first.
The keyword here is "publicly"

"A senior NATO official warns Belarus is "preparing the environment to justify a Belarusian offensive against Ukraine and the imminent deployment of Russian nuclear weapons in Belarus"" https://twitter.com/SamRamani2/status/1505964273117417477 The tweet after clarifies that deployment may not be imminent.
Moving the odds up on The Guardian reporting that according to a Nato official Belarus may allow Russia to do this soon: https://twitter.com/SamRamani2/status/1505964499534327810

I know I'm biased in that I assume no one would use nuclear weapons again. Putin has been making noise about bio/chemical weapons in Ukraine. There's also be Russian bombing near Ukraine's nuclear site. I suspect Russia would use bio/chemical or compromise Ukraine's nuclear site before deploying a nuclear weapon. If the conflict draws out and Russia doesn't have an option to 'save face' then I would suspect the probability of deploying a nuclear weapon increases.

With nothing much to show from the invasion of Ukraine, basing nuclear weapons in Belarus would feel like a tangible win for Russia and somewhat marginally give Russia more sabr√© to rattle in negotiations with west.

Will they have moved nuclear weapons into those territories, if they are not there already. Will they publicly announce they have done it, if this is indeed the case. In the past nuclear weapons' have been moved around and these movements have not been publicly confirmed. I suspect would only publicly announce this to "make a point". Russia has already made announcements in the last few weeks about how it is managing its nuclear weapons during this conflict.

The Belarusian government rubber stamped a requirement by Lukashenko to allow for the hosting of Russian nuclear weapons in the country. Belarus had given them up in 1991. A minefield of misinformation here. I will suggest that there is little advantage to allow such weapons to be sited in Belarus. A degree of control would be lost by Russia, in a country that nearly experienced a coup in recent times. Threats of allowing them to host them might be treated as misinformation and used as a potential frontline barrier to NATO. Verification as to the answer to this question, given the information war, will not be easy, so my response is 0%
Russian arsenal does not need to be moved into either country; their reach/nuclear umbrella extends into those regions as is and they would not wish to bring it closer to the NATO lines.

Updated assumptions: 50% chance Putin will use an announcement as a tool (due to recent US intelligence report) 50% chance Putin will overwhelm Ukraine before an announcement is made 30% chance China will give Putin an out before an announcement is made.
Low probability. Because ukraine is not controlled by russia. In addition, this action incite to west to do the same.

Adjusting down compared to my earlier point, because Russia in particular, and nuclear powers in general are very secretive about their nukes. Historically they've kept secrets that shouldn't have been secrets, so a change of this mindset seems unlikely, but not incredibly so. (25% ish)
Aggressive act, without other benefits
It seems Lukashenko is unlikely to want to draw further and deeper sanctions, which likely would come from basing such weapons in Belarus. However, could he refuse Putin? This seems unclear.
I think Russia moving weapons into Belarus or Ukraine is possible. It would be a dangerous escalation but it is possible that Putin will use this as a tactic.

I belive that there is a non-zero chance that Russia will deploy tactical nuclear weapons by September 2022, especially in Belarus, in the event of an escalation of tensions with NATO (e.g., as a result of a clash over arms supplies to Ukraine on the soil of one of the member countries).

It depends on China. If the Chinese decide to make a move and support Russia, including giving them a way out of the sanctions, this would not be happening. Additionally, this move will put China in a more strategic position, which is favorable for both Russia and China.
Belarus is publicly refusing to send troops into the war

I'm counting on this war/conflict not to be drawn out and Russia will lose the chance to make such a move in the time frame provided. If this moves past Sept and into the winter, Russia may consider such a move to bring about an abrupt end before conditions become more challenging.
The move to do this would be purely show since it‚Äôs not necessary for an actual attack however it could be a strong deterrent against any NATO or other aggression.

Similar rational to the question of whether a nuclear device would be detonated. Putin uses the doctrine of "escalate to deescalate". Still early days in the war on Ukraine, so this would be unlikely to occur until several months from now, if additional discouragement of NATO is warranted from his perspective. There are existing mobile systems that could carry a nuclear device or that could be added to aircraft. However, these would need to be secured, so deployment to Belarus seems more likely.
Not an unlikely move by Putin if he can see (rightly or wrongly) tactical advantage in doing so.
No reason to do so when there are nukes in Kaliningrad. Placing the nuclear forces on high alert is sufficient

1. Russia has the capability of launch short range nuclear ballistic missiles from Russia so Belarus isn't really an needed. 2. While the predominant winds have blowing south, they also blow eastward and into Russia (as they are today). 3. Russia has had mixed success with a mix of artillery, air, and missiles -- not to mention propaganda. It seems likely Russia will keep the strategy of attrition.
Mad Vlad is going to test the resolve of the entire Eastern Block of NATO countries, as well as Pres. Biden, and this may be exactly how a fledgling Russian offensive could lead him to react.
This would be a relatively cheap way for Russia to compensate for a loss in Ukraine. The worse they do there, the higher this chance rises.
An announcement that it has moved comes after an announcement that it will move...and it means they're moved. Don't think this is likely by September.
I am in agreement with the reasoning provided by @belikewater below. Thank you @belikewater for your dissertation.

Since Belarus approved the stationing of nuclear weapons and troops back in February (https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20220228-belarus-approves-hosting-nuclear-weapons-russian-forces-permanently), that hurdle is crossed. Should Russia do so, the strategic calculus on NATO/EU involvement/support to Ukraine changes considerably. Since Moscow sees the sanctions placed on it as a strategic threat, hence the comments made by Putin regarding nuclear forces, the placement of tactical nuclear weapons on Belarusian soil is a potential player in this conflict.
Because they lie, their best advantage is in signaling but not announcing

The key words in this question are "publicly announce." This question isn't asking whether Russia will put nuclear weapons in Belarus or Ukraine; it's asking whether Russia will *publicly announce* that it has put nuclear weapons in Belarus or Ukraine.

https://amp.france24.com/en/europe/20220228-belarus-approves-hosting-nuclear-weapons-russian-forces-permanently I am considering the occupied territories including Crimea as being part of Ukraine. The sanctions and economic woes of Russia will mount along with low moral and logistical supply chain issues. Lack of supplying a fighting force with sufficient hardware and ammo will leave Putin desperate. Leaders historically in Russia who experience military defeats do not last long.

This would be a huge provocation. Unless there were a huge change in conditions on the ground, such a a massive collapse in Ukraine's war effort (unlikely), with a resultant Russian postering toward Nato that's far more aggressive, it's just hard to see this. For its part, the US has not put any such weapons into the Baltic countries from what I have seen, so I have to assume some rationality on the part of Russia's geopolitical moves (although to be fair, the invasion of Ukraine does not seem to have been all that rational).

It would make sense for Putin to do so in the likely event that Russian troops become bogged down and fail to make major progress. In any negotiations this additional sabre rattle seems a likely Russian move.

Most people seem to always think about strategic nuclear weapons, but in this case I'm more concerned about tactical nuclear weapons, like the ones that can be fired from vehicles. As the war drags on and Putin does not capture his target he may feel the pressure to use those tools. The problem is that the rules of force are not clearly defined for them, and such weapons would have larger collateral damage then conventional weapons. It also raises the chance of a retaliatory nuclear strike from NATO if it's not clear what has just happened.
Because he is irrational and want a bigger statement if China is pressured
Moving nukes is a provocative move, but would be consistent with Putin's apparent desire to extract the most leverage of the situation.

As Russia continues its aggressive actions, many domestic nuclear theorists have pointed out that the use of tactical nuclear weapons is part of Russian doctrine. As Putin is confronted by the potential for Western/NATO intervention and as progress in Ukraine slows, he may be forced to either use or threaten the use of nuclear weapons as either a deterrent or as part of his strategy for the campaign. A rational actor would realize the consequences of first-use nuclear weapons but Putin has proven to be less than rational in the last two months.

>40% chance Russia, if they do move it into ukraine, will do it before ukraine is completely captured >72% chance Russia moves them to Belarus >87% chance the information will go public >59% chance Russia captures Ukraine by 2022-09-09

95% chance that Putin will continue to escalate towards a threat of a nuclear attack IF he remains frustrated by lack of success in the war and continued interference by the West (sanctions, military assistance). 16% chance that Putin will remain frustrated in that way for long enough (underlying assumptions: 80% chance Putin will overwhelm Ukraine's defences before the announcement is made, and if not, 20% chance that China will intervene to give Putin an "out" before the announcement is made). 20% chance that Putin will use such an announcement for the purpose of escalation.
Seems reasonably likely but the situation is so volatile, enmeshed and complex. There are so many countervailing hidden dynamics it is really impossible to predict with confidence
Russian are not willing to seed nuclear strength to anyneighbors because it might backfire them after their government change

I'm sceptical that this would happen for the following reasons. I) This wouldn't serve any strategic goals, what is there that can be hit from Belarus but not from Russia? II) It would be unusual for any country, let alone Russia in the middle of a war, to publicly leak any information about their nuclear weapons. III) Belarus has not shown itself to be a very reliable ally during the war so far, lot's of talk and little action, so why would Putin trust Belarus with nuclear weapons.
FSB analysts have demonstrated that Russia has until June financially; this will be resolved before September
The weapons will be moved into Belarus to put pressure on Belarus, Ukraine and the West.

After having discussed several of these posts, we now reduce the probability to 55%, to indicate that we think it‚Äôs still more likely than not, but only slightly. We think Ukraine will probably stay unstable over the time horizon considered in this question. This makes nuclear weapons in Ukraine unlikely. But Belarus is a bit like Kaliningrad, and appetite for such move appears high there. So the blended probability is a mix, tilted to more likely than not as long as we‚Äôre in a phase of escalation. In a sense, as the question says, here we‚Äôre debating the probability of an announcement, which is what we‚Äôre asked about, so the probability has to incorporate that Russia does make an announcement even if whether nuclear weapons really are moved in Ucraine or Belarus can‚Äôt be confirmed by the West.
Although nuclear weapons may be moved into those countries, I do not think Russia will do so publicly.
Odds of a public announcement - 50% Odds of action that backs up such a claim - 0%.
New changes in Belarus' constitution allow Russia to deploy nuclear weapons on its territory. Moscow might try and use such a move as a way to pressure the West stop military support to Ukraine.
Putin is acting like a trapped rat, but not conv he will announce if he takes desperate move.
Highly unlikely. Unless Putin attempts to co-opt Moldova, this placement in Belarus appears to be highly unlikely.

We think for Russia the incentive is to opt for grand displays of power, with nukes moved in Ukraine/Belarus to focus international attention on the danger and to mitigate risks of foreign intervention. In Ukraine we believe things should remain conventional conflict-wise, with Russian near-occupation and significant flare-ups of resistance.
I'm skeptical of Putins willingness to further escalate threats, considering the averse effects previous threats have had.

Following the discussion from @Jayce and @steven_meyer there are several considerations 1) Putin has already moved the weapons and is keeping it in him pocket to pull out as a threat when he needs to 2) why move nukes closer when they can be fired from a distance. It would only be a highly viable version of sabre rattling for either provocation or deterrence 3) will Putin want to escalate? Very difficult to predict as no one yet know if Putin has gone bonkers, feels he has a meeting with destiny to fulfil because he is ill, is working on some obscure plan which we don‚Äôt understand yet or has just been getting bad advice because of his isolation, or thing have not gone expected because the capability they thought was there was not because of corruption in the army. As we can cee too many variables to be sure at the moment.
Putin is a nutter. He will do what he can to exercise power via fear. If Belarus is game (game on).

The way I see it ,the most likely way this happens would be if Putin decides to deploy nuclear weapons in Belarus in order to deter further support to Ukraine from either Poland or the Baltic states. (Most likely scenario I see is Putin trying to scare Poland by deploying weapons to Brest due to it's proximity to Warsaw)
No they won‚Äôt but we might see Chemical or biological weapons of mass destruction.
The key word is "announce."

Publicly announcing moving nuclear weapons into belarus would certainly incite worldwide condemnation, however would be a non-lethal and non confrontational method to deter the west from supporting the ukraine and they are already affected by vast sanctions already. It is likely that Putin will continue taking unpredictable and unforeseen actions in opposition to his normal cool and patient demeanour, however, it may be difficult to find a base rate for this kind of event, unless perhaps you count actions like the US and USSR placing nuclear weapons in turkey and cuba during the cold war? i will change estimates as more forecasts appear.
